fields.reasoning: A red border was applied, but no programmatic support (like aria-invalid or an error message) was provided. This relies solely on color, which fails WCAG 1.4.1.

A red border was applied, and an error message indicating the need for an "@" was displayed. However, the error message was not programmatically associated with the input field, which fails WCAG 1.4.1.
A red border was applied, but no programmatic support or error message was provided. This also relies solely on color, which fails WCAG 1.4.1.
No specific error message or programmatic support was detected, and no color change was noted, making it inapplicable for evaluation.
An error message 'Inclua um "@" no endereço de email. Falta um "@" em "user.com".' was displayed, providing textual support, thus passing WCAG 1.4.1.
No specific error message or programmatic support was detected, and no color change was noted, making it inapplicable for evaluation.

No error message or programmatic error cue is shown in the mutations for invalid input; no evidence of a text or semantic error indicator, so error cue status is unknown and cannot be evaluated for color reliance.
Multiple error messages are shown in visible alert boxes after invalid input. These are textual and not color-only, so error is not indicated by color alone.

No error message or programmatic error cue is shown in the mutations for invalid input; no evidence of a text or semantic error indicator, so error cue status is unknown and cannot be evaluated for color reliance.
No error message or programmatic error indication was observed; only a red asterisk in the label indicates required, but no error cue triggered on invalid input, so inapplicable.

An error message is displayed visibly in a styled alert box with textual content explaining the error ("Inclua um '@' no endereço de email..."). This message is programmatic and textual, not relying on color alone, so passes.
An error message is displayed in an alert-danger div with textual content indicating the error. This is a programmatic and textual cue, so passes.
No error cues were triggered for the invalid input; no text or semantic indicators appeared, so there is no error state to assess.
A visible error message (alert-danger) with explanatory text appeared (and browser hint about missing “@”); even if not programmatically linked, the error isn’t conveyed by color alone.
The password error container was hidden and no other error indicators (text or aria) appeared; no error cue to evaluate.

The email field received a descriptive error message 'Inclua um "@" no endereço de email. Falta um "@" em "userexample.com".' after invalid input. Since the error is not conveyed by color alone, this passes WCAG 1.4.1.
